fields.Title of Contribution: Spatial pathogen transmission for emergent vectors with explicit host interactions for infection
fields.Description/Abstract:
Although the classical theories commonly used for the transmission dynamics of
vector-borne infections such as malaria, dengue and West Nile virus overlook
spatial heterogeneities, the distributions of larval habitat, potential hosts,
and the density and flight pattterns of the vectors all strongly influence
their transmission. Each of these creates a highly irregular spatiotemporal
patchwork through which pathogens may conduct, propelled forward by a mobile
vector sequentially acquiring, harboring, and creating infections.  To
understand systematically how these complexities, in their simplest possible
forms, influence vector infectivity, a spatial, probabilistic formalism
extending the classical theory is developed. A locally-emergent, dispersing
vector cohort is formulated to have contact interactions, or bloodmeals, with
proximal hosts for potential transmission events. Hosts are regarded as
stationary and universally available to focus on the infectious dynamics of
primarily endophagic vectors in a simple setting. A latency prior to
infectiousness in the vector is included and the mosquito population feeds and
perishes according to classic malarial models. The infectious portion of the
vector population is compared to other sub-cohorts of the emergence, including
the fed and infected populations, and found to be longer-lived. Due to their
boosted longevity, the infectious portion explores an extended region of space
about the larval source where it may infect distal hosts. The transmission
formalism is developed as a continuous space and real-time model carried out
two-dimensions, and it unites classical Ross/Macdonald dynamics with a
reaction/diffusion approach. Connections to classical malarial epidemiology are
made throughout to emphasize the role of the included mosquito dispersal.
